qas.question: What alternative name were the Greeks known by ?
What did the label of  Hellenes come to stand for during the Common Era of Greece ?
Did the Roman world consider one ethnocentric lineage to be a great concern ?
What imperative value was extolled from the Christian community to the Roman world ?

answers.text: Greco-Roman educational system, although it was from Christianity that the culture's essential values were drawn.

qas.question: What alternative name weren't the Greeks known by?
What did the label of Hellenes come to not stand for during the Common Era of Greece?
id the Roman world consider two ethnocentric lineage to be a great concern?

plausible_answers.text: Greco-Roman educational system, although it was from Christianity that the culture's essential values were drawn

qas.question: What imperative value was extolled from the Christian community from the Roman world?

context: Of the new eastern religions introduced into the Greek world, the most successful was Christianity. From the early centuries of the Common Era, <a0_0>the Greeks identified as <b4_0>Romaioi<b4_0/> ("Romans")<a0_0/>, by that time <a1_0>the name ‘Hellenes’ <b5_0>denoted pagans<b5_0/><a1_0/>. While ethnic distinctions still existed in the Roman Empire, they became <a2_0><b6_0>secondary to religious considerations<b6_0/><a2_0/> and the renewed empire used Christianity as a tool to support its cohesion and promoted a robust Roman national identity. Concurrently the secular, urban civilization of late antiquity survived in the Eastern Mediterranean along with <a3_0><b7_0>Greco-Roman educational system, although it was from Christianity that the culture's essential values were drawn<b7_0/>.
